body: +1.   LGTM.  We can correct anything that goes wrong at deployment of Geode 1.1, when we have more than one version to post.
Moving to review board.
Closing for now due precheckin failures
Precheckin started
Need to fix a few things.
Mark Doxygen as required and fix typo.
LGTM

I would suggest a little more detail on the building in windows since the command provided will use NMake and suck for the person building. Include statement about -G generator options. Maybe include links to basic CMake documentation. Maybe under each platform provide examples of building on that platform. 

I would also pull out the installation directory thing to a footnote for about `make install` as it is not necessary for build or package targets.
Let's also move the BUILDING.md down to the root directory so it is easier to find.

Looks good so far, but there are still a lot of files missing apache headers. I don't know how easy it will be to integrate [apache rat](https://creadur.apache.org/rat/) into the cmake build, but for now you can run it from the command line to get a list of files that are missing licenses:

java -jar /path/to/apache-rat-0.12.jar  .

I see a few java files, shell scripts, text files, and a lot of xml files without apache headers.
[missing_licences.txt](https://github.com/apache/geode/files/712483/missing_licences.txt)

The [geode examples](https://github.com/apache/geode-examples) look for a GEODE_HOME environment variable. I think maybe some of the scripts in the java project do as well? It would be nice to be consistent and use that instead of GEODE_ROOT.

@upthewaterspout, Its an easy change. We went for consistency with the CMake community on the explicit variable setting. It is however consistent to have the module "find" the product by environment variables if X_ROOT is not set. In our case we are looking for env:GEODE_ROOT and env:GEODE, again consistent with most CMake modules. It would be pretty easy to add env:GEODE_HOME to the list. Open a JIRA please!
@pivotal-jbarrett  - Here's a jira - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-2317.
In this push I am only trying to tackle the changing of licenses and adding to the obvious sources. We will integrated something a little more like rat (see email GEODE-2312 about rat issues).
Elegant. Looks good to me.

I've been down this ordering road before. Pretty sure this change will break on Windows and possibly Solaris. If the known to work platforms in the BUILDING doc, which have you tested this pull against?
@pivotal-jbarrett  Yes you are correct, previous change will break windows. I have updated PR. Tested on ubuntu and CentOS.
This PR fixed the issue for me on ubuntu.
This closes #341

Looking at this a little more... I don't think that gfppcache directly depends on -lz. If it is just a transitive dependency from libxml2 then we should move the -lz to target library definition for libxml2 and remove it from here. @davinash are you interested in taking a stab at that?
Thanks @pivotal-jbarrett , I have handled review comments, tested on Ubuntu and CentOS.
Precheckin passed
LGTM
Any further discussion?
LGTM, these changes typically take multiple iterations to get right.
+1 for this round
@metatype looks good if you want to merge it.

+1 on the renaming
+1 on marking the closing braces too
+1 modernizing the casting
+1 on the language specific consistencies
LGTM, Ship It!
+1 on the groups of changes identified above by echobravopapa. In particular, in addition to the namespace rename, I like the switch to nested namespaces, which will be even simpler in C++17.
Merged after rebase.
Will redo to alleviate conflicts
Looks good! Will merge.
This closes feature/GEODE-2342.
Looks good, will merge.

rejecting as duplicate of #356

Rejecting.

Path "pivotal-gemfire-*" should be "apache-geode-*".
Precheckin passed (other than an unrelated failure in `PRClientServerRegionFunctionExecutionFailoverDUnitTest. testServerFailoverWithTwoServerAliveHA`)
Messy PR, will clean up and resubmit

Hi all,

I'm really sorry I missed this. I was out of town for a while and somehow the discussion slipped through the cracks when I was catching up.

These changes are what I had in mind, but I didn't realize that this would break existing code that was doing a cast. I know adding a generics should be safe, but in this case we're fixing generics that are broken which is why I think we are getting into trouble.

I did a little messing around. It looks like we might be able to get away with adding generics to Execution. 
The only caveat is that once we add generics to Execution we are stuck with them. There is an existing bug to also add an argument type to the FunctionContext - see GEODE-2217. So I think maybe the thing to do is to add three types parameters to execution. Something like this:

```
/**
 *
 * @param <IN> The type of the argument passed into the function, if any
 * @param <OUT The type of results sent by the function
 * @param <AGG> The type of the aggregrated result returned by the ResultCollector
 */
public interface Execution<IN, OUT,AGG> {
  Execution<IN, OUT, AGG> withArgs(IN args);
  ResultCollector<OUT, AGG> execute(...)
}
```

What do you think? The other option I suppose is to deprecate the Execution class and introduce a new one, or deprecate the execute methods and introduce new ones, but that seems painful.

Or should I open a new one ?

Merged, please close.

IMO we also should add command on how to run integration run.
I could run integration tests using following command.
`cmake --build . --target run-integration-tests`
@davinash sounds like a good idea I'll have updated document today

@jaredjstewart you know more about this than I do.
Do you know why we decided to go with the Eclipse formatter rather than [Google's java formatter](https://github.com/google/google-java-format)?

LGTM
one question since I am new to CMAKE, how can we run single test ? And should we include instructions for a the same

We should include links to CTest documents.

To run singles or subsets of tests you need to use ctest directly. 

ctest -R <regex>
The latest doc in PR has instructions on running a single ctest...

It's just an integer literal value for a static constant variable called ordinal. Are you think along the lines of the remove #define statements? Is your concern determining which version of the wire protocol is supported?
I will just add a comment to the line that this is the Geode 1.0.0 ordinal.

@echobravopapa merged, please close.
@metatype We do not ship the source or binary for SQLite.

Fixed one failing clicache (ThinClientCSTXN) due to an invalid gfsh arg. Apparently gfsh still requires gemfire terminology:
   gemfire.ALLOW_PERSISTENT_TRANSACTIONS
   not geode.ALLOW_PERSISTENT_TRANSACTIONS
I don't really understand what the `48` means, but it's used elsewhere and looks something like "put everything on its own line".
See [here](https://github.com/jaredjstewart/geode/blob/GEODE-2409/README.md) to view the updated readme in your browser.
+1 - Looks great, Jared.
+1, this looks much better!
@scmbuildguy : done.
Merged, please close

+1 I'll merge the non .gitignore changes. I don't think we should be ignoring directories named bin, we actually have some code checked in those directories.

I suspect maybe you are using eclipse? The default eclipse behavior is to create an output directory called bin. If so, you should use ./gradlew eclipse and then just import the generated eclipse project into your workspace. Not only will that fix the output directory but it will setup your classpath for you!

Sounds good. Yes please ignore the .gitignore

Thank you Dan

The convention in this pull request is not consistent with the Google C++ Style Guide.

https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#The__define_Guard
closing this one and will open another PR for the same.
@jinmeiliao any thoughts on this change?
the changes look good to me. Running all tests now. Will pull this in if no test failures.
They've been googlified.
@kirklund I'm not a committer; you're welcome to commit this.
I'll merge it in.

Travis failed due to rake (I'm not sure what that even is).

rake aborted!
No Rakefile found (looking for: rakefile, Rakefile, rakefile.rb, Rakefile.rb)
`rake` is a ruby thing.  We need a .travis.yml file to build and run unit tests.
Good catch that must not be used. So we should remove it. Please create a new ticket for that.
Precheckin started

PS: I'm all for making more improvements to our format (including longer lines) and either making the eclipse+intellij formatters consistent (they produce different results presently) or moving to Google's java formatter if it's better and used in either IDE in some way.
